message.content:
<teammate-message teammate_id="team-lead" summary="Vote on "(constitutive) character" format">
The author refines the format. Instead of "constitutive character" at first occurrence, use:

**(constitutive) character (德 De)**

The parentheses around "constitutive" visually signal that the qualifier is clarifying but will drop away. Then plain "character" in running text thereafter.

Compare:
- Option A: "constitutive character (德 De)" → then "character"
- Option B (author's proposal): "(constitutive) character (德 De)" → then "character"

The difference is subtle but Option B makes the shortening feel built-in from the start — the parentheses tell the reader "this word is here to help you, but it's not part of the term."

YES or NO? Brief response.
</teammate-message>

input.content: **YES.** The parenthetical "(constitutive)" is a clever typographic solution -- it delivers the philosophical gloss while visually marking it as scaffolding, not part of the term itself. The reader immediately understands that "character" is the operative word. Prefer Option B.
input.summary: YES — prefer Option B with parenthetical constitutive

routing.summary: YES — prefer Option B with parenthetical constitutive
routing.content: **YES.** The parenthetical "(constitutive)" is a clever typographic solution -- it delivers the philosophical gloss while visually marking it as scaffolding, not part of the term itself. The reader immediately understands that "character" is the operative word. Prefer Option B.

content.text: Vote: **YES** on Option B. The parentheses around "(constitutive)" are a smart typographic move -- they deliver the philosophical context while signaling to the reader that the qualifier is explanatory scaffolding, not part of the core term. "Character" is clearly the word that will persist.
